items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

The employeeâs position, Senior Account Clerk (9FISC0242C), work hours are permanently being increased  from 12 months per year, 43.75% FTE, 910 hours per year to 12 months per year, 100% FTE, 2080 hours per year in the Fiscal Services Department at the District Office effective 07/01/16.

The employee on an unpaid leave effective 03/09/16 through 05/30/16.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 established the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $87,800 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of January 10, 2016 through February 9, 2016 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
The Medical Assistant program prepares students for positions in both administrative and clinical health care environments.  As part of the program, students need to go out into the work environment to gain practical experience in their field of study.  Therefore, students enrolled in the program at San Jose City College are to complete a mandatory 160-hrs of unpaid training. The  Medical Assistant Externship Placement Agreement serves to secure safe and professional hosting sites that allow our students to accomplish their educational goals.   
	 
It is, therefore, recommended that the Board approve these four agreements. 
	 
The agreements are between the following vendors:
	 
1)      Tuan Van Phan, MD
2)      Dr. Ayap Medical Office
3)      Aasha Pediatrics
4)      Meridian Medical Group

items.item_details:
Under the MetroEd Silicon Valley Career Pathways Grant, MetroED and San Jose City College enter this agreement to work cooperatively building an asset-based approach to the delivery of programs and services related to the MetroED Career Pathways grant. It is understood by and between the parties that the implementation of this MOU is contingent upon continued funding received by the California Department of Education (CDE).
For the MetroED Career Pathways Grant, San Jose City College shall receive a subcontract of $180,000 for completion of their agreed participation as per Exhibit A. 
As requested by the California Department of Ed, San Jose City College will provide information in the quarterly "Overview of Activities" that will describe how these funds were utilized including number of students served.
This Agreement commences on January 20, 2016 and terminates June 30,2019.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approves the MOU between MetroEd and San Jose City College.

items.item_details:
On October 13 of 2015, SJECCD Board of Trustees accepted grant funds awarded to San Jose City College from the U.S. Department of Education, Title V Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program for the project entitled SJCC Cultivamos Excelencia Project. The project period is for five years beginning October 1 of 2015 and ending September 30 of 2020 in the amount of $3,248,296.00. This is a cooperative arrangement grant between prime recipient SJCC and subrecipient UCSC. 
	 
Year 1 budget amount of $230,120 is provided as a subaward to University of California at Santa Cruz as part of Cultivamos Excelencia Project a Department of Education Developing Hispanic-Serving Institutions grant to San Jose City College. This subaward will be renewed annually, contingent upon annual renewal of the grant to San Jose City College by the U.S. Department of Education and successful project implementation.  The total anticipated 5 year budget for subrecipient UCSC is $1,080,769.

items.item_details:
Metropolitan Education District (MetroED) and SJECCD-Workforce Institute have established a formal working relationship to lead the development of the Silicon Valley Career Pathways projects and services. Workforce Institute will create and run the Silicon Valley Career Pathways Center (SVCPC) located on the MetroED campus. This center will house the Map Your Future (MYF) program and serve as a hub where business, industry and education partners work together to expand college and career opportunities for Silicon Valley Career Pathways partner institutions, which includes San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College. The goal is to align curriculum and programs via dual enrollment between the three institutions.  SJCC, EVC and WI counselors and staff will have a space at the SVCPC to meet students and support their application and registration process.  Assessment sessions and orientations will be held at the MetroED campus for students transitioning from MetroED to EVC or SJCC. 
	 
This formal working relationship will link the efforts between all MetroED Career Pathways Trust partners and the Silicon Valley Engineering Tech Pathways (SVETP) partners to better serve students under the proposed career pathways.  
	 
Via this contract, MetroED will fund Workforce Institute $650,000 ($220,000 year 2015-16 and 2016-17 and $210,000 year 2017-18) to perform these services and Workforce Institute will continue to provide services as funding allows for one additional year (2018-19) at the SVCP -MYF Center located at the MetroED campus.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Memorandum of Understanding between Workforce Institute and Metropolitan Education District

items.item_details:
On March 14, 2016, the Berryessa Citizens Advisory Council will announce the recipient of the Citizen of the Year award for 2015.  Since the award is confidential until the time of the ceremony, the name will be added to this agenda on March 15, 2016. However, Trustee Rudy Nasol is seeking Board approval to present a recognition certificate on behalf of the Board to the award recipient at the March 14, 2016, BCAC awards ceremony. 
	 
Mr. Tyler Shewey was the recipient of the award, and the Board recognition plaque was presented to him at the March 14 ceremony.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve a recognition certificate on behalf of the Board of Trustees to the Berryessa Citizens Advisory Council Citizen of the Year Award for 2015.

items.item_details:
On November 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to C. Overaa & Company in the amount of $11,347,704 to provide construction services for the Automotive Technology Building Project at Evergreen Valley College.   
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 012 includes modification of existing drainage at Loop Road /Lot-2 and south end of project site to protect the building and adjacent parking areas from storm water intrusion, revisions to rollup door framing material for added aesthetics, a credit for metal flashing not installed between structural beam and exterior wall above auto bay rollup doors, installation of the Intermediate Distribution Frame (IDF) room in storage room 117, slope adjustments at north bioswale, addition of (1) Projector screen and mount for classroom 138, revisions to electrical breakers, added smoke detectors for code compliance, installation of a duct mounted differential pressure sensor, final plumbing and compressed air connections to accommodate Furniture, Fixture & Equipment (FF&E) and smog referee equipment, credit for originally specified building security system and alarm panel due to District Standards revisions during the project, haul route asphalt and subgrade repairs due to existing irrigation leaks, Credit remaining for unused Allowance BP #5 for Landscape & Irrigation, and a credit for Structural Testing and Inspection, Geotechnical Engineering and Division of the State Architect (DSA) review costs associated with contractor means and methods activities.
	 
C. Overaa & Company submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $11,347,704
Previous Approved Changes                            $ 2,069,424
Change Order No. 012                                     $    190,843   
Total Contract and Changes                             $13,607,971
	 
The net change to C. Overaa & Company's contract as a result of all changes issued is $2,260,267, which equates to 19.92% of the original contract.  Legal counsel has reviewed this change; while the cumulative amount for change orders for this project now exceeds ten percent he has affirmed it is not applicable for this contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.  
	 
The Contract Substantial Completion Date is being extended by (52) calendar days to January 15, 2016.  The Notice of Completion (NOC) is being presented at the March 8, 2016 Board of Trustees meeting for approval.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 012 in the amount of $190,843 to C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 012
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Building, Project #32111 - C. Overaa & Company Change Order No. 012

items.item_details:
The contract for the Automotive Technology building #32111 at Evergreen Valley College, was necessary to construct a new Automotive Technology facility on the Evergreen Valley College Campus. 
	 
On November 11, 2014, the Board approved the Lease Lease-back (LLB) delivery method for C. Overaa & Company to perform the Work.  On November 24, 2014 construction activity began and on January 15, 2016, major construction activity was completed.  As of January 15, 2016, all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, the final Change Order is being presented for approval on March 8, 2016.   
	 
This approval shall terminate the following agreements:
	 
Site Lease:  In accordance with Section 7.1 Term:  the site lease between San Jose Evergreen Community College District and C. Overaa & Company dated November 12, 2014 is terminated by payment by C. Overaa & Company of all site lease costs and filing of the NOC by the District in accordance with the stated terms of the site lease agreement.
	 
Facilities Lease:  In accordance with Section 4.2 Term of Facilities Lease: the facilities lease between C. Overaa & Company and San Jose Evergreen Community College District is terminated by payment to C. Overaa & Company of all lease payments and the filing of the NOC in accordance with the stated terms of the facilities lease agreement.
	 
Once approved, this NOC will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by C. Overaa & Company for the Automotive Technology Building Project #32111 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On August 25, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Rodan Builders, Inc. in the amount of $960,000 to provide construction services for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.
Final Change Order No. 004 includes Work that is the result of costs from:  the credit from the stitch weld on the generator enclosure, the addition of data cabling and termination of control equipment, the credit from the remaining allowance balance and the addition of the revised detail for the generator door modification.  Final Change Order No. 004 also includes a $0 (zero) dollar Non-compensable (66 – sixty six) days schedule extension from November 24, 2015 to January 28, 2016 as a result of manufacturing lead time for equipment procurement and installation which extended the critical path.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                            $   960,000.00
Previous Approved Changes                      $      37,726.30
Final Change Order No. 004                       $        3,098.77
Total Contract and Changes                        $1,000,825.07
	 
The net change to Rodan Builders’ contract as a result of all changes issued is $40,825.07 which equates to 4.25% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Final Change Order No. 004 in the amount of $3,098.77 to Rodan Builders, Inc. for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On December 8, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an emergency contract to O. C. McDonald Co Inc. in the amount of $149,569 to provide construction services for Sequoia Heating Hot Water Piping Replacement Project at Evergreen Valley College.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 001 is for:
	 
Following the contract award, O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. was asked to install temporary heating hot water piping to provide hot water heating to the Sequoia Lecture building while the permanent piping is being replaced.  Alternate means of providing interim heat in lecture halls were explored before this temporary piping solution was agreed to be the least intrusive and most cost effective. 
	 
O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. submitted a written pricing proposal for this change (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount              $149,569.00          
Previously Approved Changes      $           0.00
Change Order No. 001                   $ 30,100.00
Revised Contract Amount              $179,669.00
	 
The net change to O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $30,100 which, equates to 20% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001 in the amount of $30,100 to O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. for the Sequoia Heating Hot Water Piping Replacement Project #32307-09 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The contract for the GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus Controls Extension, Project #31127, at San Jose City College, was necessary to replace fan coil units that had reached their useful end of life in classrooms of the General Education buildings, new air conditioning systems for telecom/data rooms, and new HVAC controls campus wide. The project improved thermal comfort in classrooms, and greater efficiency of operation that will minimize maintenance and energy cost for the District. This project included upgrades to the Primex clock system including a new transmitter to improve communications and provide the District with new clocks.
	 
On May 27, 2015, the Board approved the Agreement for Environmental Systems, Inc. of Northern California to perform the Work.  On June 15, 2015, construction activity began and on December 31, 2015, major construction activity was completed.  As of January 7, 2016, all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, closeout documents have been received, and all Change Orders have been approved. 
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion (NOC) will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Environmental Systems, Inc. of Northern California, for the GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus Controls Extension Project #31127.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus Controls Extension, Project #31127 – Environmental Systems, Inc. of Northern California – Notice of Completion (NOC)
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) GE HVAC Upgrades and Campus Controls Extension, Project #31127 – Environmental Systems, Inc. of Northern California – Notice of Completion (NOC)

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition or purchase order ... (to) purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency. 
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a “piggyback” contract to Enviroplex, Inc. for the supply and installation of two modular buildings (one team room building and one team room / concessions building), without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. The award of this contract will allow greater flexibility for the San Jose City College staff in providing design input by directly engaging with the approved manufacturer and will utilize DSA pre-approved (i.e. Over-the-counter) standard designs thus reducing authority review times.
	 
Attached is proof of publication (bid advertisement), board approval from Las Lomita’s ESD awarding Enviroplex, Inc. a three year contract effective 01/14/2015 to 01/14/18 and copy of their Standard Form of Agreement.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to ‘piggyback’ on a contract with Enviorplex, Inc for the modular buildings required as part of the New Gym Sitework and Auxiliary Buildings Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) New Gym Sitework and Auxiliary Buildings Project #31125 – Modular Buildings - Piggyback Enviroplex, Inc. Contract
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College (SJCC) New Gym Sitework and Auxiliary Buildings Project #31125 – Modular Buildings - Piggyback Enviroplex, Inc. Contract

items.item_details:
The contract for the Pathway/Parking Lot Improvement #31128 at SJCC was necessary to rehabilitate the South West parking lots and the replacement of various concrete walkways throughout the campus at SJCC to promote enhanced vehicular and pedestrian traffic flow, safety, and accessibility. 
	 
On June 9th, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved the Construction Agreement for Lewis & Tibbitts Inc. to perform the Work.  On June 29th, 2015, construction operations began and in 2015, major construction operations were completed.  All construction work has been approved by Underwood & Rosenblum, Inc., all closeout documents have been received, Change Orders have been approved, and all contracts have been closed.  The Board is asked to approve the Notice of Completion for the SJCC Pathway/Parking Lot Improvement Project.
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion (NOC) will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Lewis & Tibbitts Inc., for the Pathway/Parking Lot Improvement Project #31128 at SJCC.

items.item_details: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees of the San José-Evergreen Community College District approves a resolution in support of Women’s History Month, March 2016.  The District appreciates the many women students, faculty, staff and administrators who have made numerous contributions of great value to our Colleges. The District also appreciates many members within the District community who have contributed to and/or participated in the educational and celebration events in March that pay tribute to Women’s History Month, 2016.

items.item_details:
At the January 12, 2016, Governing Board Meeting, the Board received a report from the Board Policy Ad Hoc Committee, comprised of Trustees Nasol, Ho and Cruz.  President Nasol reported the committee reviewed all the policies contained in Chapters One and Two; and after requesting some additional edits, the committee was satisfied with the draft policies presented for a first reading.
	 
However, during the meeting, a concern was expressed about BP 2315 Closed Sessions. President Nasol agreed to call another meeting of the Board Policy Ad Hoc Committee to discuss the revision of this policy. Upon further review of the draft policies, it was also noted by Chancellor Budd that BP 1100 The San Jose-Evergreen Community College District, BP 2015 Student Members, BP 2220 Committees of the Board and BP 2725 Board Member Compensation also needed some additional work. Therefore, these five policies are not yet ready for approval but are being submitted in the Information Agenda-Presentations and Discussion for a second reading.
	 
All other policies contained in Board Policy Chapters One and Two, included in the attached files, are now considered ready for approval by the Board. Please note that on the policies being submitted for approval, strike-through words indicate language that has been removed from the policy and underlined words indicate language that has been added to the policy since the last Board approved version.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Board Policy Chapters One and Two, with the exception of BP 1100, BP 2015, BP, 2220, BP 2315 and BP 2725, which are being submitted for a second reading.
items.item_text: Board Policy Chapters One and Two
items.item_text_raw: 5. Board Policy Chapters One and Two

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2004 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2004 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria was added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  This criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision. In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
This Bond List Revision does not contain substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above. This Bond List Revision includes allocation of interest earnings.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revision Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on the project revision included on the G-2004 Bond List Revision dated March 8, 2016.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2004 bond list, as presented.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2004 Bond Program: Bond List Revision

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria were added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  These criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.   In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 21 does not contain substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above.  In this bond list revision request, Evergreen Valley College is transferring project savings from completed projects 32308- Utilities Projects and Upgrades and 32311-Campus Water Service Replacement Project to Project 32702-IT Infrastructure Improvements to accommodate additional budget needs. An allocation of interest earnings is also included in this revision request.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 21 dated March 8, 2016.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G - 2010 bond list, as presented.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 21
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 21

items.item_details:
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee, appointed by the Board of Trustees, has a responsibility under the provisions of Proposition 39 to inform the public, review expenditures and present an annual report to the Board of Trustees.
	 
The web-based Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee’s 2014-2015 Annual Report is presented to the Board of Trustee’s for acceptance by the 2014-2015 Committee Chair, Mr. Jimmy Nguyen.
	 
This report is available for review using the following web link:  http://cboc.sjebond.com/AR1415/
A printable version of this web-based report is also attached.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept through action the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee’s 2014-2015 Annual Report.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee’s 2014-2015 Annual Report
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee’s 2014-2015 Annual Report

items.item_details:
The District may consider placing a General Obligation Bond Measure on the November 2016 ballot.  This would be a Proposition 39 General Obligation Bond with a 55% voter approval threshold and would carry the requirement of a citizens’ bond oversight committee.
	 
The District may have a need to initiate activities and incur expenditures prior to the passing and issuance of this bond measure.  This resolution allows the District to incur reimbursable costs prior to the issuance of bonds.
	 
The consequences of not adopting this resolution are an inability to reimburse project related activities, a delay in moving forward with project planning and implementation of projects associated with this measure, and a potential delay in General Fund savings resulting from a loss of efficiency in the implementation of the program.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the resolution clarifying the Districtâs intent to reimburse project costs related to the issuance of bonds that may result from the general obligation bond measure the District may consider placing on the November 2016 ballot.

They have also prepared a brief presentation regarding their travel to the SACNAS National conference which took place in October in Washington D.C.

items.item_details: The District Facilities and Bond Program Management Office is responsible for oversight of capital projects (local bond-funded as well as other funding sources), building maintenance and repair, facility improvements, long-range facility planning and space management / reporting to the State Chancellor's Office. This presentation will provide an update to the Board of Trustees, with a primary focus on Total Cost of Ownership of facilities and work with the California Community College Chancellor's Office for long-range planning and project funding.

items.item_text_raw: 2. District Facilities and Bond Program Management Overview

items.item_details:
The Districtâs financial advisor, Keygent, and bond underwriter, Piper Jaffray, will be presenting information on financing for the Measure G-2010, Series D General Obligation Bond issuance.  This is the last issuance of bonds for the Measure G-2010 authorization.  It is expected to be approximately $58 million. 
	 
The draft Resolution, accompanying draft agenda item for the Resolution, Preliminary Official Statement, and Contract of Purchase for this transaction is included for Board review.  The final resolution and associated documents will be brought to the Board of Trustees for approval on April 12, 2016.
	 
The next steps toward issuance of Measure G-2010 Series D is as follows:
	 
April 12, 2016:  Board of Trustees meeting to approve the resolution for bond financing activities
	 
April 19, 2016:  Presentations to bond credit rating agencies
  
June 9, 2016:  Closing of bond financings/bond proceeds received by the District

items.item_details: During the review process of the Board Policy Ad Hoc Committee, the first reading provided at the January 12 board meeting, and upon further review by Chancellor Budd, it was determined that five policies:  BP 1100 The San Jose-Evergreen Community College District, BP 2015 Student Members, BP 2220 Committees of the Board,  BP 2315 Closed Sessions and BP 2725 Board Member Compensation required further review. The Board Policy Ad Hoc Committee met on Thursday, March 3, to make further revisions to these policies, which are attached. The recommended edits highlighted in red reflect the changes made to the policies after the first reading by the Board. They are now being submitted for a second reading.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
